document.title: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills for English Language Arts and Reading - Kindergarten

98ECEC808D364DFF9EBB2421A6805940.description: make connections to own experiences, to ideas in other texts, and to the larger community and discuss textual evidence.

228CD948B0D1448983B95710065C1BE5.description: retell or act out important events in stories; and

5A5ED1A3B4B1474686F541A3DFE7322B.description: make inferences based on the cover, title, illustrations, and plot;

14CADABD75794F13ACACA9FCB3470241.description: monitor and adjust comprehension (e.g., using background knowledge, creating sensory images, rereading a portion aloud);

FCDB38D11B0448CA99511BED493B3A74.description: ask and respond to questions about text;

A17E014831CC47B29B5D707E53E73983.description: discuss the purposes for reading and listening to various texts (e.g., to become involved in real and imagined events, settings, actions, and to enjoy language);

6F67606F3F604AB69B68E35D2812047E.description: Students use a flexible range of metacognitive reading skills in both assigned and independent reading to understand an author's message. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater depth in increasingly more complex texts as they become selfdirected, critical readers. The student is expected to:

AE5EEDCC6CE74609AD085524B13DF893.description: Students work productively with others in teams. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to follow agreed-upon rules for discussion, including taking turns and speaking one at a time.

164BEEDAA4384EB38ABF2059FE1D9696.description: Students speak clearly and to the point, using the conventions of language. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to share information and ideas by speaking audibly and clearly using the conventions of language.

17051F02ED884D91A10C933744F35DBD.description: follow oral directions that involve a short related sequence of actions.

38F5F20E092C40A5AAFB5DD28C07392C.description: listen attentively by facing speakers and asking questions to clarify information; and

274B4FE72C67406A84142EAEF5E5A60D.description: Students use comprehension skills to listen attentively to others in formal and informal settings. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to:

6E3A6ECE637F4EEDAF4DD1CE7254623E.description: use pictures in conjunction with writing when documenting research.

70CE462D44F14D029DAB99998F196D91.description: gather evidence from provided text sources; and

5A066013B3AE427187DC89142C9DCFD9.description: Students determine, locate, and explore the full range of relevant sources addressing a research question and systematically record the information they gather. Students (with adult assistance) are expected to:

DF865C4C24294C19AD3F01EF9B056702.description: decide what sources or people in the classroom, school, library, or home can answer these questions.

AD527E710A4740329FEE13F8057D9A55.description: ask questions about topics of class-wide interest; and

E4F12FD7E71A45A9A8DFF63F91985D8B.description: Students ask open-ended research questions and develop a plan for answering them. Students (with adult assistance) are expected to:

028BF870BDC0418595A0D7A91E17FD43.description: use letter-sound correspondences to spell consonant-vowel-consonant (CVC) words (e.g., "cut"); and

7418CB2EE6764C3CB3506858E7953213.description: use phonological knowledge to match sounds to letters;

63C300F2586143549FDE369BEBB4024F.description: Students spell correctly. Students are expected to:

44052FC946F444E3A7E4E6C25B91BA29.description: use punctuation at the end of a sentence.

6B260E4D90B748F495F628CFA369B048.description: capitalize the first letter in a sentence; and

D94470DA761B4A17BCF066B1E2C58B3A.description: form upper- and lower-case letters legibly using the basic conventions of print (left-to-right and top-to-bottom progression);

0BDA5B7846564DB5A3D6417D7A7CA636.description: Students write legibly and use appropriate capitalization and punctuation conventions in their compositions. Students are expected to:

8DD2A891E6A5467681DDA5703A7010FE.description: speak in complete sentences to communicate; and

5DD17A2FA009458084939CCA5810ACAF.description: prepositions and simple prepositional phrases appropriately when speaking or writing (e.g., in, on, under, over); and

C0F676E952FC474F8E5C281CD407AB07.description: past and future tenses when speaking;

3B5947EB73CB464BBF7836E4C424F9E3.description: understand and use the following parts of speech in the context of reading, writing, and speaking (with adult assistance):

A120B215FFAB4AAF8F9B0576509ACDD8.description: Students understand the function of and use the conventions of academic language when speaking and writing. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to:

E276A4645C374CE1B2792F8B887B8AC0.description: Students write expository and procedural or work-related texts to communicate ideas and information to specific audiences for specific purposes. Students are expected to dictate or write information for lists, captions, or invitations.

0E5015FC6EE94B1C9B5BA766ECAA8CBC.description: dictate or write sentences to tell a story and put the sentences in chronological sequence; and

8E5FEE3D805E4F80A69120FFBB404954.description: Students write literary texts to express their ideas and feelings about real or imagined people, events, and ideas. Students are expected to:

F7DF240A5B004E9FBBB6A99086950FE5.description: edit drafts by leaving spaces between letters and words; and

8317A35AAFD9410C9F9F9E1371BE3DC7.description: revise drafts by adding details or sentences;

31EA929F04E1481DBE0D5F6B26335E95.description: develop drafts by sequencing the action or details in the story;

E8DD5ED487404A6EBA54C814A5DC86E5.description: plan a first draft by generating ideas for writing through class discussion;

51F4576AB6244D0F96BD93E15B9C0B20.description: Students use elements of the writing process (planning, drafting, revising, editing, and publishing) to compose text. Students (with adult assistance) are expected to:

EA96F9450F664CD98986D61B3F4E95D9.description: identify techniques used in media (e.g., sound, movement).

BBD7093AED04468F8B42827944F43B8A.description: identify different forms of media (e.g., advertisements, newspapers, radio programs); and

8A393937EDDA4F76B70DFE3041775120.description: Students use comprehension skills to analyze how words, images, graphics, and sounds work together in various forms to impact meaning. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater depth in increasingly more complex texts. Students (with adult assistance) are expected to:

976EBEC635024DF09E798899A6D1CB70.description: identify the meaning of specific signs (e.g., traffic signs, warning signs).

805DC49519C34B75A5F80F80764F6DE7.description: follow pictorial directions (e.g., recipes, science experiments); and

2501F78EF02A45AF875A88BBDA8DBB20.description: Students understand how to glean and use information in procedural texts and documents. Students are expected to:

C2501EE861D5465A9DB6A92EAA6B93E3.description: use titles and illustrations to make predictions about text.

1885AC0D927E49C28F93D58DDD4ADDFC.description: discuss the ways authors group information in text; and

03D39EB08BD04568B14E13B3BB365385.description: retell important facts in a text, heard or read;

A60C82C031A14A419E3CAD30B230149D.description: identify the topic and details in expository text heard or read, referring to the words and/or illustrations;

7BDF06EFD6094811B9AFA1EA4E358A20.description: Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about expository text, and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

4E38CBA97BE940EE9B14DCCA6A33965E.description: Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about the author's purpose in cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to identify the topic of an informational text heard.

DFB5CC123C4D49C190E11460BB31EB59.description: describe characters in a story and the reasons for their actions.

EB831B0FA1B342B1A72737B091A67520.description: retell a main event from a story read aloud; and

D9E364DE03E34F51BAF61A1382564C16.description: Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of fiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

EA1B60EBF402458396CE3114C9EC04A9.description: Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of poetry and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to respond to rhythm and rhyme in poetry through identifying a regular beat and similarities in word sounds.

6F9C2BF73937411E8B8DE5A8C04D243C.description: recognize recurring phrases and characters in traditional fairy tales, lullabies, and folktales from various cultures.

D5A99A3B5CCF4359A5A2B3DD6987EE54.description: discuss the big idea (theme) of a well-known folktale or fable and connect it to personal experience;

294AEDAA0CEC44399CD740130CBDF40C.description: identify elements of a story including setting, character, and key events;

F1009DBA5E2B4AEB8BD448E43D1B1F3F.description: Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about theme and genre in different cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

DBBBE72D518A48BE8ABD68D4636C6239.description: use a picture dictionary to find words.

0F0643FDD3A348A7A3BC194E5BFDA053.description: identify and sort pictures of objects into conceptual categories (e.g., colors, shapes, textures); and

0D8045DBA35C4F2194DA51FFE6DB4BC4.description: recognize that compound words are made up of shorter words;

F4650A7ADD404220A8763C9059104D14.description: identify and use words that name actions, directions, positions, sequences, and locations;

DDDC0ACD8AE549749C424A7E8F814F95.description: Students understand new vocabulary and use it correctly when reading and writing. Students are expected to:

D18C7DAC2B6B4B6D9C95A2DE095C9869.description: ask and respond to questions about texts read aloud.

689024CECA0E4B46AA0583FE2809B1E5.description: predict what might happen next in text based on the cover, title, and illustrations; and

4D0604592CB34D4AA685C204D17FA6B6.description: Students comprehend a variety of texts drawing on useful strategies as needed. Students are expected to:

CEBCB6319BF04C9399068F5F40BCB8E3.description: identify and read at least 25 high-frequency words from a commonly used list.

A3B04EAFEB04487D9F58D9532420A06D.description: recognize that new words are created when letters are changed, added, or deleted; and

CF8FF38C38974054BD014C6BFE923E52.description: use knowledge of letter-sound relationships to decode regular words in text and independent of content (e.g., VC, CVC, CCVC, and CVCC words);

E28FA10BFB734CD29EEC0303904BDB4D.description: identify the common sounds that letters represent;

6EAAC0F4E39B43F4BD06CFFDD3499E2F.description: Students use the relationships between letters and sounds, spelling patterns, and morphological analysis to decode written English. Students are expected to:

013DCCD85D1D4953810B4D671612EDDA.description: segment spoken one-syllable words into two to three phonemes (e.g., dog:/d/ …/o/ …/g/).

5E4E9CF0F3DA4196833694BDC15E4C6F.description: isolate the initial sound in one-syllable spoken words; and

0882579ACC7E4C45A9FEF0D97ABFDEE0.description: blend spoken phonemes to form one-syllable words (e.g.,/m/ …/a/ …/n/ says man);

1AF8C59F2F2D4CE3B84A008846252AA2.description: blend spoken onsets and rimes to form simple words (e.g., onset/c/ and rime/at/ make cat);

B03AF754F7FD4E04B36D94A8E9EF53E3.description: recognize spoken alliteration or groups of words that begin with the same spoken onset or initial sound (e.g., "baby boy bounces the ball");

44B5EC6FBF454FC89DAC6CDADEF7B468.description: distinguish orally presented rhyming pairs of words from non-rhyming pairs;

033F11EEDF8D43F9B059F00EDA87B80B.description: orally generate rhymes in response to spoken words (e.g., "What rhymes with hat?");

6D13127130C740E6973A44BCB7BFDACF.description: identify a sentence made up of a group of words;

7384AE8D1D6C4889A033C2C24A7E5618.description: Students display phonological awareness. Students are expected to:

3B1C68EE39044DF08722111401EC112E.description: identify different parts of a book (e.g., front and back covers, title page).

097CE7DB00754A47B03EE1C4BB393520.description: hold a book right side up, turn its pages correctly, and know that reading moves from top to bottom and left to right; and

196F08367429435897F20BCF63024FF4.description: recognize that sentences are comprised of words separated by spaces and demonstrate the awareness of word boundaries (e.g., through kinesthetic or tactile actions such as clapping and jumping);

9840F9B57FEB468A90B68D1B1BFEA3CF.description: recognize the difference between a letter and a printed word;

D742CD046FA64BD9A6512B272C8FEAD9.description: demonstrate the one-to-one correspondence between a spoken word and a printed word in text;

C8FAC1E2183046B8A53329AE4E3C65A5.description: recognize that spoken words can be represented by print for communication;

17F5782DBA114120975F51A8D51A27EC.description: Students understand how English is written and printed. Students are expected to:
